article.title: The 14-3-3 proteins of Arabidopsis regulate root growth and chloroplast development as components of the photosensory system
article.abstract: The 14-3-3 proteins specifically bind a number of client proteins to influence important pathways, including flowering timing via the photosensory system.

sections.introduction: The 14-3-3 proteins are predominantly known for their ability to bind certain phosphorylated proteins to complete phosphoregulation events (Ferl, 1996).
sections.methods: Arabidopsis seeds were sterilized as previously described by Paul et al. (2001).
sections.results: Wild-type and 14-3-3Î¼-1 were grown on vertical MS media agar plates under constant light conditions and assayed for root lengths after 8 d of growth.
sections.discussion: This study characterizes several novel functions of 14-3-3 proteins in root growth and chloroplast development.

article.insights_summary: This study reveals new developmental roles of 14-3-3 proteins in roots and chloroplasts, probably via association with the photosensory system.
